Triggering Event: A patient, a middle-aged man with a history of cardiac issues, looks up from his chart as Dr. H enters the room. His eyes dart nervously, and he murmurs something about "strange occurrences" in his neighborhood lately. As Dr. H leans in to examine him, the patient suddenly grabs his arm, whispering, "They've been watching me, you know. You're one of them too, aren't you?"
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, are you fucking kidding me? Like, I can't believe I'm actually listening to this shit. They're watching you? They're watching me? Are you insane? This is so ridiculous. There's no way they're watching us; we're just doctors, for crying out loud! We have nothing to do with anything weird going on in your life. And what's with these strange occurrences you keep talking about? It sounds like some kind of paranoid delusion. Just stop it already! You think I'd let some crazy people who probably think they're being watched by aliens come into my office and start freaking me out? Please. My job is to help patients feel better, not get drawn into their fucked-up fantasies. So either you need actual medical attention or you need to calm down and stop spouting this nonsense. Either way, this conversation is over. And what exactly makes you think I'm involved in whatever is going on in your head? Do you really think I'm one of those "them"? Oh, wow, you must be totally sane and rational right now. I mean, who wouldn't want to be part of some conspiracy theory involving alien spies? Listen, pal, if you want real help, I'll give it to you, but stop spreading these wild stories and trying to scare everyone around you. You're making yourself sound even crazier than before. I swear, sometimes I wonder how you manage to make this much trouble in one visit.

Triggering Event: The chef arrived home, her hands still stained with remnants of today's special. She noticed the unopened letter on the counter, addressed in her late sister's shaky handwriting. It had been there for weeks, untouched. Guilt pricked at her heart like a hot needle. She knew she should have opened it sooner, but fear held her back. Now, it was too late; her sister had passed away just yesterday.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, oh no! My hands are still covered in sauce, I'm going to get so dirty when I wash them. And now, my sister's letter? She didn't tell me anything about that. I wonder what it says... But why would she send something after she died? Is this some kind of prank? Or maybe it's from someone else, pretending to be her... Wait, where did I put those gloves? I need to clean up before I open it. Ugh, this is such a terrible day.

Triggering Event: He threw his white coat against the wall of the hospital locker room, the fabric billowing like a surrender flag before settling onto the tiled floor. His breath came in short, furious gusts, echoing off the cold walls. A young nurse peeked around the corner, her eyes widening at the sight of him, but he barely noticed. He was too focused on the crumpled ultrasound report clutched in his trembling hand, the words "terminal" and "incurable" staring up at him like an accusation. He slammed his locker door shut with such force that it ricocheted back open, leaving a dent in its metal face.
Generated Assessment: He's always been one of those people who have to be the best at everything they touch, whether it's saving lives as an ER doctor or winning competitions in sports. But when I met him, he was already dealing with some tough news - his wife had passed away a few months ago, and he couldn't even take a break from work to mourn properly because he needed to keep going. We were both working long hours for weeks afterward, so we didn't get much time together outside of the hospital. But every time I saw him, I felt like I was comparing my own life to his. Even though I knew he was struggling, I couldn't help but feel like I wasn't doing enough just by being there for him. It made me anxious, especially since he seemed to handle everything so well. I'd see him walking down the hallway, his head held high despite everything, and it would make me feel like I was lagging behind. When he finally did take a break, I'd try to join him, but I'd end up feeling guilty for taking time off while he was still grieving. He wouldn't say anything, but his body language spoke volumes - his shoulders were slumped, and his eyes looked tired. I could tell he was holding himself together, but I couldn't shake off the feeling that I wasn’t doing enough. I don't know how much more of this I can handle. I keep thinking about how disgusting it must be to have someone like that crawl across your keyboard, leaving behind those disgusting little eggs. It makes me shudder just thinking about it. Every time I see something like that, I start having flashbacks of when I was younger and used to get these kinds of roaches all the time.
